author: karalabe
content:
Geth implements the rules outlined in Edelweiss, an up-to-date rundown can be found in out blobpool PR

https://github.com/ethereum/go-ethereum/pull/26940

author: karalabe
content:
- Replacing a blob tx requires a 100% fee bump on all components
- The minimum priority fee is 1 gwei
- A replacement blob tx cannot evict already pending ones with overdrafts
- Normal and blob txs are mutually exclusive (across the entire nonce range). If on type is pooled, the other is rejected until the pool empties. I.e. you cannot replace a blob tx with a non-blob one.
- Included blob txs are kept in limbo until finality to support resurrecting back into the pool on reorgs

author: karalabe
content: ^ to answer the questions raised in your doc about Geth

author: karalabe
content: Blob txs are not broadcast ever, resurrecting back into the pool may entail reannouncing them, but only to peers not yet announces, so relistically probably to noone or just a couple new peers

author: karalabe
content: Geth's blob pool by default is currently capped at 10GB, but should operate perfectly fine with 100GB too per our tests

author: karalabe
content: The storage cap is disk based, it has a more-or-less insignificant RAM hit

author: karalabe
content:
> seemed we still lack consensus on transaction pool rules for blob transactions

Geth's implemented rules are not up for debate or consensus FWIW. I can gladly discuss any potential issues with them, but these are design choices to support the high capacity of the pool and to avoid hitting the same issues that have been plaguiging the main txpool. Happy to be made aware of flaws in my logic and course correct of course, but I don't want to lightly reconsider base assumptions.

author: karalabe
content: PS: Due to the consensus clients not sending us blobs with the payload, we can already not resurrect included-but-never-seen blobs. I consider that a very nasty thing tbh, but my hands are tied if CLs dont want to play ball.

author: roberto.bayardo
content: Thanks for the detailed response Peter, and yes I used the term "broadcast" loosely there, "reinject" is more appropriate (doc updated).

author: roberto.bayardo
content: (p.s.: goal of my doc isn't to re-litigate but to surface & socialize the thinking around these concerns given where things seemed to stand in the last client devs call)
